Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Development of an interferometer-based Coordinate Measuring Machine
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader/commercial impact of this Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project is to advance high-accuracy, rapid, on‐shop floor or in‐machine dimensional measurements of precision machined parts. These measurements are conducted with Coordinate Measuring Machines (CMM), representing a $4 B market. The proposed project will develop a new portable CMM instrument for precision machine shops, bottlenecked by their high‐cost stationary CMMs or limited by low-accuracy portable CMMs. In‐machine part inspection will reduce waste for one‐off or prototyping shops. It will further improve CNC machining process control of large batch jobs by allowing rapid statistical sampling of the accuracy of CNC-machined parts mid‐process. The new technology will improve efficiency and accuracy in machine shops, lowering the cost of manufactured parts. <br/><br/>The intellectual merit of this project is to surmount two primary technical hurdles needed to complete a working prototype of the new interferometer‐based Coordinate Measuring Machine (CMM). These hurdles include the development of an absolute distance interferometer measurement system, tuned specifically for the novel CMM, and the development of the custom mechanical, optical, and data acquisition/processing systems required for its function. The new interferometer‐based CMM will have multiple inherent advantages over existing portable CMMs, including sensitivity, absolute accuracy (tied directly to the wavelength of light) and long‐term reliability. The novel approach addresses many challenges in the 3D metrology domain. Research tasks include diode laser frequency locking with high absolute accuracy, merging of multiple absolute distance interferometry methods, construction and optimization of the mechanical and optical systems, and integration of software and hardware.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project funding has enabled the development of an absolute distance interferometry measurement system, consisting of mechanical, optical and and data acquisition/processing components.  Software and hardware has been developed to perform 3 steps of absolute distance measurements, with the first step based upon laser wavelength (frequency) scanning, achieving 60 micrometer accuracy with an ambiguity length of over 1 meter, the second step based upon two wavelength phase measurements, achieving 2 micrometer accuracy with an ambiguity length of 216 micrometers, and third step, based upon single wavelength phase measurments, achieving 10 nm accuracy with an ambiguity length of less than 1 micrometer.   To achieve these results, two diode lasers have been independently locked to different optical absorption features of a molecular gas cell (standard) with an accuracy of better than 1 part in 100 billion.  The entire absolute distance measurement system is controlled by a set of custom software program which provide a user interface for inputing required parameters, integrating all interferometer phase measurements, performing the laser ramping,  calculating the intermediate and final absolute length of the interferometer channel and displaying the results. While the demonstration of these capabilities was performed on a single interferometer channel, the software and hardware system is designed to perform identical measurements in parallel on multiple interferometer channels.
